turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: Marcus Aurelius has died.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: He left us at dawn.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: We must obey our emperor and the Senate.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I met with Falco, and the Senators have agreed to call for a truce with the Germans.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: This is the only place in Rome where I thought -- I believed -- I was wholly in power.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: Narcissus will never support you, Caesar, he has too much of a philosophical temperament.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: It's because he comes off as the underdog.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Underdog!  How can he be an underdog -- he wins all the time!  I'm the emperor why can't I kill him?  He could be poisoned, or somehow killed to look like an accident.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: You don't want to kill him.  If anything happens to him now you will be blamed... and he knows it. Besides, that gladiator school is a fortress.  It would take the army to break in there.  What you want is to... offer him the wooden sword. If he takes it, he's no longer the champion of the people, is he?  He's gone.  And you are a hero for awarding it.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Where is my father?

turns.speaker: TRIBUUS
turns.text: Where is the emperor and the army, soldier?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Tribuus, what happened in the arena? Was Narcissus killed?

turns.speaker: TRIBUUS
turns.text: He must have been.  He was on the list of prisoners to be executed.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Why isn't he dead?  Damn you, you promised me he would be dead!

turns.speaker: TRIBUUS
turns.text: Caesar, I did my best.  The Colosseum isn't under my control...

turns.speaker: TRIBUUS
turns.text: Yes, Caesar?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Jerses -- tomorrow...

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Tribuus!  Go left here, I want to see my new statue at Via Claudia.

turns.speaker: TRIBUUS
turns.text: Yes, Caesar.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: We need more statues -- perhaps I should open medical clinics.  For the poor.  Citizens only, though...

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: You won an impossible fight.  You got the attention of the crowd, legate...

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: This is Cos, this precocious young man.  A scribe for the Daily Action.  I've invited him to write a small piece about you...

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: I'm mentioning you in tomorrow's athlete's section, legate.  So, I'd love to know your birth sign; it effects how people bet.  And perhaps you could tell me a bit about... well, who are you?

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: "Caesar Commodus discovering his lineage converges with the Demigod, Hercules, has determined to display his magnificence before his beloved citizens."  The Emperor's going to fight in the arena.  I'm supposed to write this for tomorrow's edition.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Commodus... he's a gladiator... is he mad?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Cos, what in hades is the emperor up to?  And don't tell me you don't know!

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: AGH!  Please!  He's having a secret device constructed for the circus. The brass craftsmen are working overtime.

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: I'll nose around...

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: You know there were riots last night.  Now the unrest has started again and Commodus has sent for an army division.  You understand what you are doing...

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: So tell me, what happened between you and the emperor?  What really happened on the German front?  You know the Senate's arguing your case...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: That's their job, isn't it?  To argue.  So, I think my case will be long on talk and short on action.

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: I am prepared to write anything you tell me.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: My birth sign is Water Bearer, twenty-fifth day in the month of Janus.

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: The exact month when the Emperor must be confirmed!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: The Emperor and I are bound by the threads of The Fates.  He was born on August thirty-first, you know.

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: That makes his birth sign... Virgo! Why that's the sign of a little girl!  Can you tell my readers more about your star-crossed connection with Emperor Commodus?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Proximo, we need to talk about my one third... I imagine the betting booths will be doing good business. And, what was the name of that olive oil company?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: It's time for you to tell the Citizens that Commodus stole the money allocated for defending the German border.  It's time to tell the citizens everything.  Will you write it?

turns.speaker: COS
turns.text: Yes, because I know they'll read it.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: The battle was won, today, and I prefer to believe it was a gift of Janus, the eldest God of Rome.  God of my ancestors.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: God of passages and changes?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I believe we are arriving in an enlightened age; an age of peace that will bring Rome her greatest glory.  Thanks to Marcus Aurelius.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: You know, general, there is a Gate of Janus in Rome which is only closed in time of peace.  Sadly, it has remained open for three hundred years.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I've read of it.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: But have never been?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: My only visits to Rome, Senator, have been through books.  But the war's over, time to close the door of war once and for all.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I would venture, with all respect: the Emperor's health is the business of every soul in the empire.

turns.speaker: GAIUS
turns.text: Yes!  The days of Imperial Prerogative and disdain for the Senate are over -- thanks to your father!  Now report to the Senate, Master Galen:  what is Marcus' state?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: A republican is a man who strives to create equality among all classes.  At the core he's a man who believes in doing what's right.

turns.speaker: GAIUS
turns.text: The trouble is defining exactly what 'right' is.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: We all know what right is, Senator.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: The Senate too?

turns.speaker: GAIUS
turns.text: The moment you returned from the battle your options were clear.  If you are a friend to neither side, legate, you must be an enemy to both.  We needed to know what you believed.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I hope you live to see what I believe...

turns.speaker: GRACCHUS
turns.text: Who are you?  Narcissus The Good?  I have heard of Narcissus Meridas. That's who I hear you are.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: You're hearing about somebody else.

turns.speaker: GRACCHUS
turns.text: How did you get condemned to the arena without a trial?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: When the Senate and the Emperor agree miracles can happen.

turns.speaker: GRACCHUS
turns.text: Would you support the Senate if they would give you a trial?  You'd have to give me your word.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I need to give you my word when yours is worth nothing?

turns.speaker: GRACCHUS
turns.text: You're a citizen and a soldier.  Not a gladiator.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: You don't know how wrong you are.

turns.speaker: JUBA
turns.text: You on your way to trial, too, general?  Or do you think they've already had our trial?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Why you?

turns.speaker: JUBA
turns.text: My loyalties... were in doubt.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Fools to let us both live; we'll be our own best witnesses at our trial.

turns.speaker: JUBA
turns.text: That's what worries me...

turns.speaker: JUBA
turns.text: Is this Rome?  Are we just going to be executed?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: They can't... if this is Rome...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: No future-telling, please, I've been terrified enough for one day.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Narcissus!  Terrified?  You?  The only thing he's scared of is me.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: You know our two most senior Senators:  Gaius Cantus and Falco Verus?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Only from a distance.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: I thought all good generals were quick to recognize opportunities.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Sneaking around with your brother?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Without him.  He'd be weeping if he overheard that.  Well?  The idea of you as my adopted brother is very... exciting.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I'm not fit for the job and as a matter of fact I'm not taking the job.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Why do you keep playing at being so humble?  It's a little embarrassing.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Why do you play at being drunk?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: How do you know I am playing?  Well, the clown is always harmless.  Isn't that right?  And how did you ever get to know me so well?  The last we spent any time together I was fourteen.  I think you know me better than my father.  He's going to die, isn't he?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I don't believe that.  He's got the best doctor in the world and a will of iron.  You know we're preparing for a full-blown invasion of Germany.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Of course I know -- who do you think is paying for it?  The Emperor himself, didn't you know?  Why do you think Commodus came rushing up to the front?  Burning patriotism? Filial love?  He wants to be sure when he takes over there's enough cash left in the treasury to... play Emperor.  Watch out for him, Narcissus; he's inexperienced, but... be careful.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: It's my brother's neck you want, not mine.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Yours will do!

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: I came here to see that you stay alive.  The people need a living breathing alternative to Commodus, a hero.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: You mean a symbol of someone who doesn't exist.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: But you do exist.  Narcissus:  hero of the battle of the Danube.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Twenty years I've led men to die. For me it was the glory of Rome. But that was something.  If it wasn't that, then it was the pay or the loot of the next whore -- but that was something!  These men here are butchered for laughs!  Their lives are like jokes delivered in the back alley theaters where their death is a punch line!

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: For the sake of the Gods, you're not leading these men?  How like my father you are.  You 'believe'... I guess that's why you're still alive.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: To think I brought my daughters up on all things Roman.  Read to sleep on Catullus, Lucretius... Virgil... every night.  My beautiful daughters.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Do you remember your Epictetus, that little homily we recited when we were children?  The one that was supposed to remind us we were Romans?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: "If you consider yourself to be only one thread of many in the tunic, then it is fitting for you to be like the rest of men, just as the thread has no desire to be any better than the other threads. But..."

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: "But what if I wish to be purple?"

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: You cannot die.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Would that Marcus had lived.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Marcus would have lived but... was poisoned by his son.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: He killed his father and then my family...

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Narcissus, I have your family. They're alive.  All of them.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Where are they?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Hidden.  Where my brother cannot place hands on them.  He didn't have the guts to watch them die so... I took care of it all.  The sooner he is put out of our misery, the sooner will they be safe.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: Commodus, it's we who are going on the offensive.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: The fort helps position us for a final invasion in the spring when they're most vulnerable.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: Commodus -- listen to Narcissus, listen to the man who has never lost a battle for Rome!  You're young with years ahead of you before you gain the experience to wear the purple!

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: I want you to start your work for the last phase of the campaign.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I will, Marcus.  But you're going to be well enough to direct it yourself.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: I've made so many mistakes, Narcissus.  We all put off the very last duties of our lives because we're afraid of admitting when our lives are over.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: There's no reason to say that. Everyone knows you're going to be well.  I had Servis groom your horse for a triumphal visit to the front at first light.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: Servis made it through again?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: He's like you, sir, too tough for the Gods to swallow.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: If I'd ever had a sign that you wanted to rule I would have... no, again, it's my own bullheadedness. Narcissus, I should have adopted you years ago.  And now the Gods are begging me to make you my son!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Commodus is just a young man, he'll learn what you had to learn.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: It's not because he's young, it's because he's ignorant and arrogant. His sister is a better man.  That's why I have undertaken to begin sweeping changes in the relationship between the emperor and the Senate.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: So I understand.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: Everyone talking about it?  I wouldn't wonder.  All I seek is a genuine balance of power between the Emperor and the Senate.  Thus I have transferred legal power -- which was theirs to begin with -- back to the Senators.  This includes a shared right to taxation too but some bite in the plan.  It's a start, only a start.  If the Emperor and the Senate can share power then the people will be ready to take their share.  This means Commodus has to bend; does he strike you as that type?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: You're too hard on him.  He is a strong young man, with you as his guide...

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: A man should be upright, not be kept upright.  History shows us that a good general is quick to recognize opportunities -- even if it means making a complete about face at the last minute.  I want you to consider becoming my heir.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Marcus, you honor me, but I'm a soldier, politics scare the hell out of me.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: The Senators admire you.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: They fear me.

turns.speaker: MARCUS AURELIUS
turns.text: They fear change.  The new Caesar must be honest enough to know when the emperorship is no longer feasible.  You could be the one, the Emperor, the man who oversees the rebirth of the Republic.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I'll do anything in my power to help you restore the Republic but I can't be that power.

turns.speaker: THEMIS
turns.text: I made the plume from a quail feather.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Much more colorful than the ones we wear.  And, of course, less dented.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Don't stop to visit -- take the children straight home and I'll follow as soon as I can.

turns.speaker: THEMIS
turns.text: Tomorrow?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: As soon as I can.

turns.speaker: THEMIS
turns.text: On your honor as a Roman officer, daddy?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: On my honor as your daddy...

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: I see the emperor's little boy has finally caught up with the army.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Let's hope he doesn't start giving orders.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: What the hell was all that about?

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: What the hell do you think it was about?  There's nothing an unproved heir to the throne likes less than glaring competence in others.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Why don't we try to keep politics out of the conversation.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: Well, we can try...

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: Serious stuff...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Centurions on both sides of the river are convinced the Germans will try one last offensive.  They've got nothing to lose and it's so very like them.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: Everyone knew you would have been outspoken against this deal.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: What deal?

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: Rome is going to pay an allotment to the German tribes on an annual basis.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Rome is going to pay tribute -- like a defeated nation begging for mercy? Have you told your troops that?

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: My troops don't make policy.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Well, they die for it!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: On his death bed I promised Marcus I would complete our work here.  The Senate may be vacillating, but I have the army behind me.  I'm taking half a cohort and restocking that fort.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: I can't let you do that.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: You brought the army into Rome.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: I was summoned.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: It's your job as a Roman officer to disobey such a summons.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: It's my job to keep my job.  And that, by the way, is now head of Praetorian Guard.  Good ole Tribuus has been retired.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Quintus, you've got at least a division with you -- we could take Rome away from Commodus and give it back to the Senate!

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: You seem to be doing a great job of it single-hand!  Narcissus, the Republic is dead.  You think those Senators could govern?  For the last hundred and fifty years they've worked hard at kissing an endless succession of Imperial asses!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Then give the empire back to the people... the children who will grow up to become senators...

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: The 'people'?, listen to the people, they know what they want:  A government that gives them what they need and doesn't bother them with messy thoughts of issues.  You know, messy... thinking.  They want a dictator!  As far as the children, there is only one thing that every Roman child dreams of:  being you! A famous gladiator!

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: What are you fighting for in here? The good of Rome?  I can end this madness now!  Take the job for the sake of the Gods, live!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Can you stop that slaughter?!  Can you free these men?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: He's very realistic.

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: Isn't the helmet magnificent?

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: Well, you wanted the girls to have the best teachers.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Greeks?

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: Athenians...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: What about their philosophy lessons?

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: They're studying with Cynics.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Of course...

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: You need to come home!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I can see that...

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: The battle is over.  The war is over.  You've won!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: If you win, you know, you have to stay.  It's the losers who get to go home.  Besides, I'm not so sure it is over.  Centurions report enemy scouts probing our lines.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: This is our oil from our estates?

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: I've been overseeing production myself for the past three years, you'll be surprised at how wonderful our oil has become.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Very fancy.  Did you design the bottle?

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: Who else?  I'm the one who runs the estates while you're here risking everything we have for the glory of Rome!  Or for the glory of you!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I'm a soldier -- we're at war.  I can't stay home tending the damned olive groves?

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: We don't need your help we're doing great on our own.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I want to come home, of course I do, I'd have to be mad not to want that. It's just that Marcus trusts me.

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: Let him trust Quintus.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Quintus is overly idealistic.

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: I never knew a more idealistic man than you.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Me?  Well, I believe in Rome... you'd have to after what I've seen, how people outside the empire treat each other.

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: I don't even want to imagine the things you've seen...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: What you don't want to imagine is the things I've done.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: When you get to Ostia, use this -- bribe passage to Africa or Spain. Save my family.  You should be able to find a merchant ship that will take you to Egypt then to Numidia.

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: You're not going!  You have to stay with us!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: How long do you think Commodus will let us live once he's in power?  A month?  Half a year?  Paestum will be a prison where he'll hold us until it's time...

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: Narcissus!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Do you want to see Themis and Manto butchered?  If I die fighting Commodus he won't care about you. If I live I'll come and get you.

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: I don't want you to die!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I'll never die.  You tell the girls that.  You honor our ancestors and I'll be there.  Every night.  At the table of life.

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: Your daughters need more than some vapors; they need you!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: They'll have me.  Teach them.  Don't let them become like these ignorant heaps of citizens without history, without philosophy, without meaning. Teach them of the Greeks, the Babylonians, the Hebrews, the Numidians, the Egyptians and the great Romans.  Teach them, who we are!

turns.speaker: SELENE
turns.text: You teach them!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: That's what I'm going to do.  That's what I'm going to do...

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: You're a legate in the Roman army. Huh...?  and you act like one. What was your crime?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I killed too many barbarians.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: I'm a Greek, thank you.  And I was brought up believing Romans were the barbarians.  Give our new colleague some of the Cretan white.  Relax, tell me everything, I'm your friend.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Who the hell are you?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: I am the man who might save your life -- give you a bit more life at any rate.  I am Proximo Palindromos head of this gladiatorial school which is named after me.  I own this school and everything that's in it.  You're in it!  But why?  What did a Roman general do to get himself condemned to the Colosseum? Understand, we usually get corn thieves and pick pockets.  Please, I separated you from the others because...  ... my nose tells me you've been condemned for important reasons.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Condemned?  Aren't I owed a trial before being condemned?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: General, all I know is you have been condemned to the Colosseum, and a trial is nowhere to be seen.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Impossible!  Every citizen has a right to trial -- this is Rome!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Thank you.  What is going to happen tomorrow?  Exactly?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: You are to be killed, exactly. They'll give you a sporting chance, but just enough to make your murder... entertaining.  Romans like to mix their metaphors:  laughter with their executions, you know?  If you survive, though, you will become a gladiator.  A gladiator at least gets a fair fight.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Death is a very light thing for you.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Death is... everything for me.  Now you have to go to your cell, and I to dicker with Jerses... you'll be fed well.  I want you to be fit as you can be; I want you to win for me tomorrow!  I want all my gladiators to win and be happy!  Besides, I've never owned a Roman general before.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Take your hands off me animal!

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Chain him.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Sorry but I have to get at least one fight out of you otherwise I won't even get back the cost of the bribe I had to pay the arena slaves to get you here.  I know what you're trying to do:  kill yourself and trust in the Roman tradition of justice that the emperor will let your family survive and keep their lands.  The only thing you have accomplishes is to prove you're a very important individual.  You make me feel good about my investment!  And that puking pig Jerses -- he won't even discuss you.  Both of you have clamped mouths!  But I love all my fighters -- I'll find out about your family.  And about you.  That I promise.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I refuse to be your slave.  I refuse --

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: -- to fight?  We'll see...

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Legate Narcissus Meridas, general of the Spanish Felix Legions!  I'm proud to have you in my school!  Now, show them what you can do!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I'm not a gladiator.  I refuse to fight.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Then, you'll die...  Just, know this:  because you asked I asked:  I'm sorry but...

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: General, do you realize what happened out there today?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I didn't get killed and everyone else did.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: That's one way to look at it.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: At the end of the day I was approached by the Golden Pompeii Olive Oil company.  Small, but profitable.  They asked if you would endorse their oil.  We could get some very nice posters.  Make some very big money...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: What would the poster say: "Narcissus would kill for a taste of Golden Pompeii Olive Oil?"

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Think about it!  Just think about it!

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: General, hang on... drink slowly. You are blessed by the Gods to have a physician and a Divine of Janus with you tonight.  A fan sent them to you.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Alive... I'm alive...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Proximo, if this is her doctor he's an assassin.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: It will be good luck for you to wear that helmet... It belonged to Cimon of Smyrna... he was crushed by an elephant.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Lucky it didn't step on his head.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: No more bad luck now!  The people are anticipating you!  I have posters up over half the city advertising you as the great warrior -- the true Roman!  The man who fought side by side with the wolf of Rome!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Make us rich, Proximo, make us very rich...

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Tiger's challenged you and Jerses has made me an offer, made us both an offer:  you take a fall.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: What the hell are you talking about, Greek?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: You put this inside your shirt -- when Tiger stabs your stomach -- it's full of pig's blood.  Gushes out everywhere!  It's really impressive.  Fantastic!  Better than the real thing!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: So I pretend I'm dead.  You get gold, what do I get?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: You get to come alive again in the country!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: As, what, 'The Galloping Gladiator?!'

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: The point is you get to fight the easy country circuit, the small arenas, relax, live the good life!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Spend my days beheading country bumpkins?  I don't know, Proximo, who has better wine than you? Besides, I'm beginning to think of the Colosseum as my home.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: But -- you have to go out there! I'll give you more than your one third!  When I get paid... just take the fall!  You're too hurt to fight and the man's a killer!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Pressures on, eh Proximo?  There's got to be a load of money in this. Why else would you toss a red hot commodity like me out the window?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: It's absolutely not like that!  This is for your own good!  Come on get the rest of your armor on!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Tell me honestly, since this may be our last earthly meeting:  if this were a fair fight where would you put your money?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: On you!  Of course!  You are my bravest fighter -- the best fighter I have ever seen!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Such nobility from such an ignoble mouth.  Take my advice and make that bet.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Oh, shit.  Take your time!  Don't get suckered!  This man is a murderer!  In his career he's killed over a thousand gladiators.  Please, just take the fall!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: How much money is involved?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: A great deal.  They designed and build Tiger's chariot...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: They want to dump Tiger and have me endorse their damned chariot, right? They don't waste time...

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: I can really rape them on this!  Can I at least tell them you'll think about it?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: No.  Tell them I'll do it.  But I want more posters all over Rome.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Fantastic!  Wonderful!  But posters are very expensive.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Then get a large cash advance.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Right, right... But they'll have to bring in a lawyer.  I don't want to get sued over this.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Before they leave, get gold.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Right, right, what am I thinking of?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I want another interview with Cos. Tell him to bring plenty of ink.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: I'll do it!  Sure as there's shit in the Tiber we're all going to die, but for you -- anything!

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: So, things change.  The government has moved to the circus.  You're going to fight last.  And Commodus is going to fight first.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: You were a soldier, and then a gladiator, weren't you?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Was I?

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Let's talk about this later.  Right now we have other things to settle. You and your family will be leaving with a supply ship returning in the morning to Ostia.  From there, Caesar has decreed you be given an estate in Paestum.  It's beautiful; an old Greek town right on the ocean.  Rich soil.  Perhaps we could keep our financial arrangements... although Caesar will give you a sort of pension it's always good to look to the future, keep your hand in the arena... so to speak.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I want nothing to do with the arena.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Something else, then.  Do the chariot races interest you?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Commodus must hate you.  Free your gladiators and come with us.

turns.speaker: PROXIMO
turns.text: Are you mad?  With all this unrest the Colosseum will be open day and night!  Anyway, I'm not political, I'm in the entertainment business.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You're living at home now. Is that right?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Do you know what you're going to do?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Are you going to graduate school?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Do you always drive like this?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Do you want some dinner?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I'd love some.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Aren't you eating?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: If it's all right with you, I'm not hungry.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Benjamin -- do you dislike me for some reason?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No -- why should I?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Could you do it?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Will you take me home now?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm sorry I took you in there.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I think I'd better go home now please.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But, Elaine --

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Where is the car?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I just want to tell you something.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I want to go home.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But could I just tell you this one thing?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: This whole idea -- this date and everything. It was my parents' idea. They forced me into it.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Oh -- that's very nice of you to tell me.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No. What I mean is -- that's why I've been acting this way. I'm not like this. I hate myself like this.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Listen -- could you stop crying, please?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No, I couldn't.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But could you try?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I've had this feeling -- ever since I've graduated -- this -- kind of compulsion that I have to be rude all the time. Do you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Yes, I do.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Would you like to come in? I could make some coffee.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No, I mean -- I wouldn't want to wake anyone up.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: We won't. Let's go inside.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Wait a minute.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Is anything wrong?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No -- I was just thinking -- look -- it's still early -- we could do something -- go somewhere else.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Where we going?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm trying to think of where there's a place to have a drink around here.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Isn't there one in the Taft Hotel?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What is the matter?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Nothing. I'm just wondering if they have a bar or not. I mean let's go see. Let's go see if they do or not.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Listen, Elaine -- it seems to me that there isn't a bar in here. I mean -- as far as I know.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Of course there is. Look -- The Veranda Room -- right there.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Benjamin --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Let's get out of here, Elaine. Let's go somewhere else.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Benjamin -- do they know you?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Ben -- what's happening? Who is Mr. Gladstone?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I don't know. They must think I look like this guy Gladstone.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You're the first -- you're the first thing for so long that I've liked. The first person I could stand to be with.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I'm sorry. That is not my business.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: It just happened. It was just this thing that happened along with everything else. Can you understand that?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Was she married or something?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: With a family?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yes. She had a husband and a son.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Did they ever find out?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: And it's all over now.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I'm glad.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: During the day? We'll go for a drive or something.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You sure you really want to?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Because I wouldn't want you to do it unless you really wanted to!

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You do?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Benjamin -- I really do.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You've got to go over the back fence and I'll meet you on the corner.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Benjamin -- what's happening?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Hurry up. Put your shoes on.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Why aren't you ready?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Because I want to know what's happening.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: That woman --

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: That woman. The older woman.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You mean the one who --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yes. The married woman -- it wasn't just some woman --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Elaine --

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Oh my God --
